Reopening rules and guidance are ultimately determined by your local county government. Please visit your county website for the latest information about reopening rules in your community.

Beginning at 5:00 PM on June 19, gyms, indoor fitness establishments, malls, arcades and casinos will be allowed to open at 50 percent capacity. All patrons and employees must adhere to #COVID19 public health guidelines.
Outdoor activities, like mini-golf and go-karts, will also be able to resume, operating at 50 percent capacity.

Maryland will also allow indoor dining to resume, with restaurants operating at 50 percent capacity and tables spaced six feet apart. Restaurants, employees and customers must follow #COVID19 public health guidance to protect against the spread of the virus.

Beginning at 5:00 PM on Friday, Maryland will allow summer school, non-public special education school and child care centers to reopen with a limit of 15 children/students and staff per room. https://www.baltimoresun.com/coronavirus/bs-md-hogan-wednesday-20200610-werxiv7dancrhntfrsyrht2ae4-story.html

I’m grateful that the Armed Services Committee is taking this step forward. Donald Trump should listen to his own party members and Pentagon leaders who recognize that it’s time to respect generations of loyal US servicemembers and rename these bases.

I'm still urging our military leaders to take action now, and to be thoughtful about who we memorialize going forward. We should honor the contributions of Black, Brown, Native, & women servicemembers & others who have served.

Changing the names of our bases won’t erase the history of slavery and legacy of white supremacy in the US. We’re fighting for legislation, oversight, and accountability to root out systemic racism. But it’s long past time to stop honoring this ugly legacy.

That’s not all. Under this new agreement, the Pentagon would be required to remove all names, symbols, displays, monuments, and paraphernalia that honor or commemorate the Confederate States from all @DeptofDefense assets – ships, barracks, and other military property.

Last week, I filed an amendment to the annual defense bill to rename all bases named for Confederate generals. Yesterday, Senate Armed Services Committee members reached an agreement: the US military must rename those military installations within 3 years.

As of June 9, IHS reports an 8.5% positive testing rate – but we don’t yet know the full picture of the extent of the virus in Indian Country. Federal efforts must be improved to help our Native American brothers & sisters fight this pandemic.

In #Alaska, we need to understand the potential of kelp & seagrass to capture & store carbon long-term, & take steps to safeguard these ecosystems. We have an opportunity to combat the physical impacts of climate change & mitigate the amount of carbon in the atmosphere—a win-win.

This legislation will strengthen federal research initiatives focused on blue carbon, improve our understanding of how blue carbon ecosystems can advance larger climate goals, and set measurable targets for the protection and restoration of coastal blue carbon ecosystems.

Alongside @SenWhitehouse, I introduced the Blue Carbon for Our Planet Act, legislation focused on protecting and valuing blue carbon as a sink for atmospheric carbon. https://www.murkowski.senate.gov/press/release/senators-introduce-bill-to-combat-impacts-of-climate-change- http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1271229429684080640/pu/img/T3YkyoRqNbx0vT9I.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1271229429684080640/pu/vid/480x270/IdTBYf67tuU1DSmG.mp4?tag=10

Blue carbon ecosystems—like kelp, seagrass, & salt marshes—play a critical role in protecting our shorelines from erosion & providing nursery habitats for our fisheries, while also storing an incredible amount of carbon—making them an important tool for addressing #climatechange. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1271228796901957638/pu/img/N9UmXQS9jTzML1vw.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1271228796901957638/pu/vid/480x270/Iaf2oJot82BO7it4.mp4?tag=10
